title: Why did the Spanish give the Louisiana Territory back to the French in 1800? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s a matter of the fortune of the moment. Spain by 1800 has not produced anything of great value or discovered anything of high technology, as she had concentrated only on taking gold, silver, and every other valuable natural resource from its conquered lands in Mexico, Central America and South America. And, by 1800 most other countries produced new things of value due to the Age Of Enlightenment and That Of Reason, while Spain lived off of her plunder. When France was developing more modern ships and cannon, Spain stood still. Additionally, Spain was now running out of easily plundered materials and was cash short. Unlike South America to Mexico where Indians had a thousand years of gold and silver and jewels, North America was filled with forests, and pelts, and cotton and other materials that the Spanish did not consider as valuable, as their assets in the South or West of America so they gave them away to Spain under the threat of having them taken away. Spain was not in the position of standing up to the militarizing French and gave over Louisiana to them. In just a few years, France, now in dire straits with Britain, sold Louisiana to the United States, which gave France an injection of money, The US The Gateway across the continent and control of the Mississippi, and a lot fewer headaches for the French, as they could concentrate on their European War. It all goes back to money.
